en: Largely intact; broken and restored on shoulder.

Antheia, standing 3/4-view to the left, with her head profile to the right, wears a white, belted chiton, a dark himation draped over both arms and held in both hands, and a sakkos. Peitho, standing profile to the right, with her weight on her left leg, and her right leg relaxed, wears a sleeveless, belted chiton with a long kolpos, a sphendone, and two bands on each wrist, holds a small baton in her left hand, and reaches her right hand to an unidentifiable object (a game for the child?). A female figure (Eukleia?), seated profile to the right on rock, wearing a medium-sleeved chiton, a dark himation wrapped around her legs, a sphendone, and earrings, raises her left hand thoughtfully toward her lowered head, and holds a small bird in her raised right hand. A young, nude boy, Kephimos?, runs profile to the left, wearing amulets around his chest, left foot, and wrist, reaches both arms to the bird. In front of a laurel (?) tree stands Eunomia, in 3/4-view to the left, wearing a sleeveless, belted chiton with a kolpos and long hair. She reaches her right hand to the tree, and holds a plate of fruit in her left hand, at waist level. Paidia, standing profile to the left, wears a sleeved chiton, a himation draped over her left shoulder, a sphendone, and earrings, holds an unidentifiable object in her left hand, and dangles a beaded necklace from her right hand.

Machaira interprets Antheia as one of the Horai. Jucker (67) has interpreted the unlabelled character as Eukleia on the basis of her cult association with Eunomia, or Aphrodite (who is usually accompanied by Peitho); an alternate interpretation has been provided by Kron (291) who identified her as Herse, mother of Kephalos, on the incorrect assumption that the boy is the Attic hero Kephalos, rather than Kephimos. On the speculative basis that this white-ground lekythos served a distinctly funerary purpose, the unidentified mother, and the child Kephimos may represent merely a mortal mother and son, as paralleled on grave stelai. Although Paidia and Peitho are both laden with erotic overtones, the innocent nature of this scene discourages us from ascribing particular erotic connotations in this context.
